sentences.sentence: From the archive As part of our Platinum 70 Year, we take a look back at opinions and reports from The Australian Financial Review on significant domestic and international events over the past seven decades.Our editorial of October 12, 1964 noted that the first Olympic Games held in Asia were more than just a two-week sporting event: they were also a pointer to the direction of world affairs.RECORD FOR THE GAMESWith the preliminaries completed to the usual accompaniment of bickering, grizzling and pessimism, the Olympic Games are now under way at Tokyo.

In terms of the number of competitors taking part, this is the biggest Olympiad ever held; in terms of the facilities which have been provided, it is easily the most elaborate.Indeed, the economic statistics associated with the Games bid fair to outshine any records that might be set by competing athletes.
It is estimated that in the past four years nearly Â£1500 million has been spent on projects directly or indirectly associated with the Games.
An investment of this order quite properly raises questions as to whether it is really justified.
The Japanese, who are not exactly tyros at economic management, have shown few doubts on this score, however.This is not surprising.
Projects that were timed to be ready for the Olympics have already had a far-reaching effect on the overall Japanese economy.

The new standard-gauge railway line between Tokyo and Osaka has greatly eased the country's greatest transportation bottleneck - a bottleneck that one leading Japanese industrialist once estimated added 5 per cent to the cost of almost every export item.Tokyo's new system of elevated trunk highways has eased traffic congestion.

This has not only made the world's biggest city a more livable place, but has also helped reduce costs for its thousands of factories.It is impossible to value parks, swimming pools, sports stadiums and flowers in the streets in terms of pounds, shillings and pence.
Nor can a precise economic benefit be calculated for the transformation of a drab and rather ramshackle city into a modern and frequently beautiful metropolis.
But these have all been a direct result of Tokyo's success in being appointed host city for this Olympiad.Melbourne knows what this is all about very well.

When the decision to give the 1956 Games to Melbourne was originally announced, there was the usual chorus of gloomy predictions from the knockers.Melbourne didn't have the facilities for such an event, there was no accommodation for foreign visitors, Australians weren't capable of organising on such a scale, there was no money available.
There were, of course, muddles and mistakes during the period of preparation and the Games themselves.

The Japanese have had the same experience and, being human, will no doubt make mistakes during the Games themselves from time to time.Melbourne held an Olympiad which was, by all accounts, one of the best-organised ever - and ended up with a deficit of several hundred thousand pounds.
But who today remembers the miscalculations of the planners of the prognostications of the gloom-mongers?

Who even recalls that Sir Robert (then Mr) Menzies offered to double the original Commonwealth Bank overdraft guarantee in order to save the Games organisation from financial chaos?What people do remember is that the City of Melbourne held one of the greatest sports festivals in history.

Around the world, from Tokyo to Tehran, Melbourne is more often than not the only Australian city whose name is well-known to the man in the street.It is perhaps not irrelevant to note that Melbourne's share of overseas investment in Australia appears to have been higher than Sydney's.
And while even an Olympiad could not provide a Harbour or a Bridge, it did provide the people of Melbourne with the finest complex of sporting venues in the southern hemisphere.

Is it inconceivable that a Sydney Olympiad might have provided an eastern suburbs railway?The concrete benefits arising from preparations for the Olympic Games, as well as intangibles such as international publicity and the creation of social capital, explain why cities around the world vie with each other so furiously for the chance to play host to an Olympiad.

The 18th Olympiad, which opened amid fanfare and ceremony in the graceful National Stadium on Saturday, is in many respects an appropriate symbol of our changing world.Those who dismiss it merely as a rather overblown two-week sporting event are not only dismally unimaginative, but lack any perception of the course being taken by the mainstream of world affairs.For the Tokyo Olympics are the first Games to be held in Asia.

They dramatise the contrast between the industrialised, developed "north" and the primary-producing underdeveloped "south" which so exercises world finance ministers.The symbolic importance of the Tokyo Olympiad is strengthened by the fact that the National Stadium is located within the precincts of the shrine set up to honour the memory of the Emperor Meiji - [who], was responsible for the amazing leap his country made from feudalism to industrial capitalism.

As the athletes of the developing nations compete on equal terms with those from industrially advanced nations during the coming days, there is a lesson in Japan which the new countries of Asia and Africa might profitably ponder.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
